prior_works.title: Finite Automata and the Representation of Events in Nerve Nets
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the equivalence-class view of regular languages that underpins the paper’s Myhill–Nerode–inspired metrics for assessing whether a model’s implied state partition matches the minimal DFA of the domain.

prior_works.title: Linear Automaton Transformations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Completes the Myhill–Nerode theorem formalization, directly motivating the paper’s use of distinguishability by suffixes to evaluate recovery of latent world states.

prior_works.title: Learning regular sets from queries and counterexamples
prior_works.role: Algorithmic precedent (DFA identification via distinguishing strings)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces L*’s use of distinguishing suffixes for state separation, a core idea the paper adapts into evaluation metrics that probe whether a generative model’s outputs respect the minimal DFA’s state distinctions.

prior_works.title: Inferring regular languages in polynomial updated time (RPNI)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows how positive/negative samples can induce minimal DFAs, informing the paper’s framing of world-model recovery from observed model behavior without oracle queries.

prior_works.title: Equivalence notions and model minimization in Markov decision processes
prior_works.authors: Robert Givan, Thomas Dean, Matthew Greig
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Connects behavioral equivalence to state aggregation/minimization, paralleling the paper’s use of DFA-state indistinguishability as the criterion for a coherent world model.

prior_works.title: World Models
prior_works.role: Concept origin in ML (learned world models)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Popularizes the notion that learned systems can internalize environment dynamics, directly motivating the paper’s question of whether generative models implicitly recover such world models.

prior_works.title: Generalization without Systematicity: On the Compositional Skills of Sequence-to-Sequence Recurrent Networks (SCAN)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates that models can pass surface-level tests yet fail systematic generalization, motivating the paper’s stronger automata-theoretic diagnostics that uncover incoherent latent state structure.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s core contribution—evaluating whether a generative model recovers a coherent world model by testing its latent state partition against minimal DFA structure—stands on two intertwined threads. First, the automata-theoretic backbone comes from the Myhill–Nerode theorem (Myhill; Nerode), which characterizes regular languages via indistinguishability classes and minimal automata. This lens naturally yields evaluation criteria: if a model has the right world model, its behavior should honor the same equivalence classes and be separable by the same distinguishing suffixes. Angluin’s L* algorithm operationalizes these ideas through membership/counterexample queries using distinguishing strings, while RPNI shows how minimal DFAs can be recovered passively from samples—both directly informing how to probe and reconstruct the model’s implied state partition from observed generations. Complementing this, work on equivalence and minimization in MDPs (Givan, Dean, Greig) provides a behavioral abstraction perspective—bisimulation-like equivalence—that aligns with Myhill–Nerode in the deterministic setting the paper studies. The second thread is the ML motivation: Ha and Schmidhuber’s World Models popularized the goal of learning internal environment dynamics, and subsequent benchmarks like SCAN revealed that models often appear competent yet fail systematic generalization. The present paper unifies these strands, proposing automata-theoretic metrics that transcend surface diagnostics to expose incoherent latent state structure in generative models across games, logic, and navigation, and explaining the fragility observed on subtly varied tasks.
